Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 33-year-old quadriplegic male who presented to the ICU with a seizure and respiratory failure. The patient has a history of motor vehicle accident (MVA) 10 years ago, and the current symptoms may be related to that. The patient was intubated due to refractory seizures and has been given antibiotics for suspected meningitis. The patient also has bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray, indicating potential pneumonia. The patient requires pressors for hypotension and has a right femoral line placed. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 35.9°C (96.7°F), heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 99/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 14 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 21 cmH2O, and plateau pressure of 19 cmH2O.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 15.9 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 11.5 g/dL, platelet count of 210 K/uL, blood glucose level of 129 mg/dL, sodium level of 0.6 mg/dL, potassium level of 3.6 mEq/L, chloride level of 7 mg/dL, bicarbonate level of 35.2%, creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL, and magnesium level of 2.1 mg/dL. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.19. Other lab values are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is unresponsive and intubated. His cardiovascular examination shows normal heart sounds, and his respiratory examination shows rhonchorous breath sounds. The patient has no lower extremity edema and his skin examination is not assessed. Neurologically, the patient does not follow commands, responds to noxious stimuli, and has not been assessed for movement or tone.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient is suspected to have seizure, fevers, respiratory failure, and potential sources of fevers include pneumonia and meningitis. The patient is being loaded with kepra and will have a lumbar puncture (LP) performed. Broad antibiotics will be continued.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, and septic shock is also a possibility. Broad coverage for pneumonia will be continued, and an LP will be performed. The patient will continue to receive intravenous fluids (IVF) and weaning of levophed will be done as possible. Weaning of mechanical ventilation will be done
